title.value: Interpretable machine learning for finding intermediate-mass black holes
title.justification: This is the title of the paper.
title.quote: Interpretable machine learning for finding intermediate-mass black holes

extractions.description: The paper explores the application of interpretable machine learning models to predict globular clusters (GCs) that may host intermediate-mass black holes (IMBHs). It addresses the limitations of traditional machine learning models by employing methods for explainability and interpretability, such as the anchors method for XGBoost and natively interpretable models using Certifiably Optimal RulE ListS (CORELS). The study uses data from simulations and evaluates real data for potential IMBH host candidates, providing a measure of prediction confidence and out-of-distribution flags.

type.justification: The study involves empirical data such as simulations and actual observations of globular clusters. It also evaluates the performance of machine learning models on these datasets.
type.quote: Definitive evidence that globular clusters (GCs) host intermediate-mass black holes (IMBHs) is elusive. Machine learning (ML) models trained on GC simulations can in principle predict IMBH host candidates based on observable features.

name.justification: The study specifically focuses on the interpretability and explainability of machine learning models applied to astrophysical data.
name.quote: Here we employ techniques from these fields to address them: we use the anchors method to explain an XGBoost classifier; we also independently train a natively interpretable model using Certifiably Optimal RulE ListS (CORELS).
